children.name: to get rid of sth that is causing problems
get rid of
children.definition: to remove or deal with sth that is causing you trouble, such as an illness or a problem: vứt bỏ , giũ sạch
examples: ▪ I can’t seem to get rid of this cold.
▪ We’ve cleaned the carpet twice, but still can’t get rid of the smell.
▪ Weedaway is a safe and natural way to get rid of weeds coming up in the garden.

children.name: scrap
children.definition: to end a system, law etc, or to decide not to use a plan that you were intending to use: loại bỏ, hủy bỏ
examples: Plans to build a new airport have been scrapped because of lack of funding.
The president’s proposal to scrap the program has angered many members of Congress.
We believe that car tax should be scrapped.

children.name: ditch
children.definition: /dɪtʃ/  to get rid of something because you do not need it: bỏ đi, "lật xuống hào"
examples: ▪ Investors ditched stocks that were performing badly.
▪ Brumfeld apparently ditched the car near Texarkana and fled into the woods.

children.name: do away with
children.definition: /duː əˈweɪ wɪð/  to get rid of sth so that it does not exist any more: giũ bỏ
examples: ▪ San José State University is doing away with its business school and department of journalism.
▪ All countries in the region should commit themselves to doing away with weapons of mass destruction.

children.name: eradicate
children.definition: /ɪˈrædɪkeɪt, ɪˈrædəkeɪt/  to completely get rid of something such as a disease, a social problem, or something that causes these things: diệt trừ
examples: ▪ The disease has been eradicated from the Western world through the use of vaccines.
▪ Their aim is to eradicate child poverty in the country within 10 years.
eradication/ɪˌrædɪˈkeɪʃən, ɪˌrædəˈkeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun] sự diệt trừ
▪ The eradication of the beetle has led to a five-fold increase in crop yields.

children.name: eliminate
children.definition: to completely get rid of sth that is unnecessary or unwanted: loại trừ
examples: ▪ Traffic police intend to eliminate congestion caused by illegally parked vehicles.
▪ Advances in medical science have eliminated the need for many patients to spend long periods of time in hospital.
elimination[ U ] C2 the removal of something
elimination of
the elimination of lead in petrol
the elimination of disease/pain
their elimination from the competition

children.name: root out
children.definition: /ˌruːt ˈaʊt/  to completely and thoroughly get rid of something that is causing you problems, especially by trying to make sure the causes of it are found and stopped: trừ tận gốc
examples: ▪ The new president has promised to root out high level corruption.
▪ Wherever we find waste and incompetence we will root it out.

children.name: to get rid of sb that you don't like or need them any more
get rid of
children.definition: loại bỏ
examples: New police chief Brody promised to get rid of the city’s drug dealers.
The company announced that it will get rid of another 500 workers by the end of the year.
One of the administration’s first tasks will be to get rid of many of the officials appointed by the previous president.

children.name: purge
children.definition: if the leaders of a political organization purge a group of people from that organization, they get rid of them because they have political views that they strongly disagree with: thanh lọc, thanh trừng, khử bỏ
examples: Many radicals were purged from the party in the early seventies.
In the North, Sung systematically purged those whom he considered a threat.
purge[C or U]
Stalin’s purges of the 1930s

children.name: eliminate
children.definition: weed out to find out those people who are not suitable to belong to an organization or group, and get rid of them: khai trừ
examples: We do have procedures in place to weed out individuals who are corrupt.
The report claimed that there were at least 20,000 inefficient teachers that needed to be weeded out.

children.name: root out
children.definition: to try hard to find out all the people who are not suitable to belong to a particular group or organization, especially when it is not easy to know who they are, and get rid of them: diệt trừ tận gốc
examples: The Ministry of Health is continuing its efforts to root out incompetent doctors.
At that time, a secret branch of the National Police was involved in rooting out dissidents.

children.name: sb will have to go U
children.definition: sb will have to goalsosb has (got) to goUS spoken  say this when you no longer want to employ someone: ai đó cần phải ra đi
examples: It’s been decided. Murrow will have to go.
‘Gates has done nothing but divide this city. He has got to go,’ said one of the protesters.

children.name: to get rid of sth you don't want
get rid of
children.definition: sth to remove sth that you do not want or do unotse any more, for example by giving it to sb else or throwing it away: vứt bỏ, tống khứ
examples: ▪ Let’s get rid of some of these old books.
▪ I hate these chairs. I wish we could get rid of them.
▪ We finally got rid of all that old junk we had stored in the basement.
▪ I think it’s time we got rid of all these old toys.
▪ If you hate that furniture so much why don’t you get rid of it and buy some new stuff.
get rid of something for somebody
▪ Give me the empty bottles -- I’ll get rid of them for you.

children.name: dump
children.definition: to throw away sth dangerous or sth no one wants, especially by leaving it in an unsuitable place: vứt bỏ (rác)
examples: dump something in/into something
▪ People who want to get rid of old cars sometimes dump them in the woods.
▪ Toxic waste is being dumped into the ocean.
▪ The half-burned bodies were dumped in mass graves.

children.name: discard
children.definition: formal to throw away sth that you no longer need, especially by dropping it on the ground or leaving it somewhere you should not: loại bỏ, vứt bỏ (bừa bãi)
examples: ▪ People who discard their litter in the streets should have to pay heavy fines.
▪ A child had become trapped in a refrigerator discarded in a vacant lot.
discarded[attri]
▪ The police believe that the fire was started by a discarded cigarette.

children.name: throw away
children.definition: to get rid of sth by putting it somewhere where it will be taken away and destroyed: vứt bỏ
examples: Don’t throw away these boxes - I might want to use them later.
Oh, no. I think I’ve accidentally thrown the invitation away.
chuck away/[M] informal to throw sth away
It’s a nice dress. It would be a shame to chuck it away.
In the bin there were a few scraps of food his mum had chucked away.

children.name: throw out
children.definition: alsochuck outespecially UK informal /toss outUS informal  to get rid of something, especially when you are trying to make a place more tidy or to make space for new things: vứt bỏ, tống khứ
examples: ▪ My wife made me throw out my old tennis shoes.
▪ Can I throw these newspapers out, or are you still reading them?
▪ You haven’t thrown those magazines outhave you?
▪ We chucked a lot of stuff out when we moved house.
▪ She would do nothing for days then spring into action and spend a day throwing out all the garbage, cleaning the bathroom, and dusting.
▪ Why don’t you toss out all those old books. You’ll never want to read them again.

children.name: dispose
children.definition: of formal to get rid of sth that is difficult or unpleasant to get rid of: vứt bỏ, xử lý
examples: The company has been charged with illegally disposing of hazardous wastes.
Police are still puzzled as to how he managed to dispose of his victim’s body.
Please dispose of this wrapper carefully.
Nuclear waste can cause serious damage to the environment if not disposed of properly.
disposal[U] B2
dispose of
We need new legislation to ensure the safe disposal of nuclear waste.
This is an incinerator for the disposal of hospital waste, such as used syringes.

children.name: get shot of
children.definition: UK informal to get rid of sth, especially sth that you have been wanting to get rid of for a long time: giải phóng
examples: ▪ I can’t wait to get shot of this old car.
▪ Everybody’s in a rush to get shot of their shares in the company.

children.name: sth will have to go U
children.definition: sth will have togoalsosth has got togoUS  spoken if you say that sth will have to go you think it should be thrown away, especially because you do not like it: cần phải ra đi
examples: I can’t stand this carpet. I’m sorry Larry, it’ll have to go.

children.name: scrap
children.definition: to get rid of an old machine, vehicle etc, and use its parts in some other way :
examples: Two aircraft carriers are being scrapped this year.
Hundreds of nuclear weapons have been scrapped.

children.name: to get rid of a leader, sb in authority etc
get rid of
children.definition: to get rid of a leader, sb in authority etc: loại bỏ
examples: He’s a terrible manager -- it’s about time they got rid of him.
Local people desperately want to get rid of US troops on the island.
The trustees of the University are considering getting rid of him.

children.name: overthrow
children.definition: to take power away from a leader or government, especially by force: lật đổ, đạp đổ
examples: President Kassem was overthrown and murdered in 1963.
The dictatorship was overthrown after a year of fighting, in which thousands of people were killed.
overthrow [U] cuộc lật đổ
He came to power after the overthrow of Haile Selassie.

children.name: oust
children.definition: written force a leader out of his or her position of power: hất cẳng
examples: ▪ Nusabe was ousted in a coup late last year.
▪ Reformers have expressed concern that he could be ousted by hard-liners opposed to his reforms.
ousted[attri] trục xuất
▪ Supporters of the ousted dictator have been rounded up and jailed.

children.name: depose
children.definition: be d if a political leader, king etc is deposed, their power is taken away from them: bị phế chức, cách chức, bãi chức
examples: He was deposed after more than 18 years in power.
Moreau was deposed in a military coup and fled to the US.
deposed[attri] phế chức
The deposed king will set up a government in exile.

children.name: to get rid of harmful ideas or influences
rid sth of
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not usually in passive]
children.definition: rid something of/ˈrɪd something ɒv/  to get rid of something bad or harmful so that they no longer exist in a place or organization: thoát khỏi cái gì đó
examples: ▪ Scientists hope to one day rid the world of this terrible disease.
▪ McCarthy wanted to rid America of the ‘evils of Communism’.
▪ I can’t seem to rid my mind of what happened on the day of the accident.

children.name: free sth of
children.definition: to get rid of ideas, behaviour, influences etc that are considered bad or harmful and have been present for a very long time: giải phóng khỏi cái gì
examples: Neighbourhood Watch schemes have succeeded in virtually freeing the area of crime.
Aid organisations are trying to free the country of the ravages of two decades of civil war.

children.name: dispel
children.definition: to get rid of beliefs, ideas or feelings from people’s minds, especially if they are false or harmful: xua tan
examples: dispel rumours/notions/doubts etc
The Central Bank attempted to dispel rumours of a possible financial crisis.
In an interview Monday, the Foreign Affairs Secretary tried to dispel doubts about his handling of the crisis.

children.name: to have got rid of sb/sth
be rid of
children.definition: sb/sth to have got rid of sb/sth, so that they are not there to worry or annoy you: thoát khoiẻ
examples: At first I was glad to be rid of the extra work, but then I realized how much money I was losing.
The sooner we’re rid of this government the better.
You shouldn’t even think about buying a new car until you’re rid of your current debts.

children.name: see the back of
children.definition: be glad/happy to  British informal to be very pleased you have got rid of sb/sth: hạnh phúc vì đã thoát khỏi
examples: I’ll be glad to see the back of this project.
We will be glad to see the back of Williams, that’s for sure.

children.name: shake
children.definition: verbshook,shakenGET RID OF
examples: [ T ] to get rid of or escape from something
It's very difficult to shake the habit of a lifetime.
The company has so far been unable to shake(off)its reputation for being old-fashioned.

children.name: cut
children.definition: verbcutting,cut,cutREMOVE
examples: [ T ] to remove something from something else
The sex scenes had been cutout ofthe English version of the film.

children.name: eliminate
children.definition: verb
examples: [ T often passive ] to defeat someone so that they cannot continue in a competition
He was eliminated in the third round of the competition.

children.name: chase
children.definition: verbGET RID OF
examples: [ T + adverb or preposition ] to run after a person or an animal in a threatening way in order to make them leave
He used to chase the childrenawayfrom his apple trees.
She's always chasing catsoutof the garden to protect her precious birds.

children.name: take sth down
children.definition: takesthdownphrasal verbREMOVE
examples: to remove something that is on a wall or something that is temporary, or to remove astructure by separating its different parts
I've taken the pictures down.
